sections.heading: Overview
content: Patty S. Freedson, PhD, is a professor and the Graduate Program Director in the Exercise Science Department at the University of Massachusetts/Amherst. She teaches undergraduate and graduate courses in exercise physiology, physiology of training and conditioning, pediatric exercise physiology, and physical activity and women's health.

She has more than 95 publications in the scientific literature and has published several book chapters related to various aspects of exercise physiology. She has been a researcher on grants received from the CDC, foundations, corporate sponsors, and the National Institutes of Health.

She was a member of the Planning Board for the Surgeon General's Report on Physical Activity and Health, and she served on the advisory committee for the International Life Science Institute and Center for Disease Control Physical Activity and Nutrition Program for Children and Adolescents. She is a past-president of the Research Consortium of AAHPERD and the New England Chapter of the American College of Sports Medicine. In 1996, she was the recipient of the Presidential Citation Award from the American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, Recreation, and Dance. In 2001, Freedson was one of the President's Lecturers at the National American College of Sports Medicine Conference in Baltimore. In 2003, Freedson delivered the Cureton Fitness Lecture at the American College of Sports Medicine Conference in San Francisco. In 2004, she was the recipient of the Chancellor's Medal and delivered the Distinguished Faculty Lecture at the University of Massachusetts.

Freedson is a fellow of the Research Consortium, the American Academy of Kinesiology and Physical Education, and the American College of Sports Medicine. She has also been a member of the Board of Trustees of the American College of Sports Medicine.
